results.title: Olympic Legacy: this was forever
results.creator_credit: Mark Aitken, Polkadotsonraindrops and First Light
results.brief_description: Set in East London, the location of the 2012 Olympics, this documentary follows a community’s battle to prevent their allotments being swallowed up in the development plans. This powerful film looks at what happens when a diverse group of people are united in despair about the effects of change.
results.description: Set in East London, the location of the 2012 Olympics, this documentary follows a community’s battle to prevent their allotments being swallowed up in the development plans. This powerful film looks at what happens when a diverse group of people are united in despair about the effects of change.

results.title: My Grandma
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Taylor, Smith and Watson Productions, Wide Eyed and First Light
results.brief_description: Jamie is a girl who just wants to enjoy herself. However, she is constantly called upon to care for her demanding Grandmother. She is tired of hearing tales of Grandma’s childhood whilst missing out on her own. Successfully demonstrating the difference between two generations of women, will her Grandma’s constant nagging and complaining push Jamie too far?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoffrey Taylor, Smith and Watson Productions, Wide Eyed and First Light

results.title: A Mile in our Shoes
results.creator_credit: Daniel Walker, Karl Armstrong, Steph Winward, The Junction, Middlesbrough Football Club Study Support, Riverside Studios and First Light
results.brief_description: The average age of a young carer in the UK is 12. This is a poignant and moving tribute to those many young carers tending to parents or siblings or both. They manage the domestic needs of a household as well as the physical needs of those they are caring for. They sometimes care for more than one family member with ailments ranging from autism to muscular dystrophy. With a constant lack of understanding from the rest of the world, no wonder there is little time for sleep let alone a social life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Daniel Walker, Karl Armstrong, Steph Winward, The Junction, Middlesbrough Football Club Study Support, Riverside Studios and First Light

results.title: Destination Point
results.creator_credit: Bloom Productions, Argyle Primary School and First Light
results.brief_description: Year 5 Primary school pupils from Kings Cross explore the ethnic diversity of their area and school. Kings Cross is an international destination point. Thousands of people travel in and out of the station every day. Some are travelling through on their way to somewhere else, some come into work and others travel to Kings Cross and make it home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bloom Productions, Argyle Primary School and First Light

results.title: The Box
results.creator_credit: Felix Drake, Phoebe Flemming, eShed, Watershed and First Light
results.brief_description: This short drama is a tight observation of family life during the recession. Shot in a single living room, we see the ebb and flow of family life reflected in some pivotal moments through a particularly difficult time. However, the digital hearth remains a constant source of comfort.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Felix Drake, Phoebe Flemming, eShed, Watershed and First Light

results.title: Beloved
results.creator_credit: Daniel Zinkant, Elle Farnham, Suited & Booted Studios and First Light
results.brief_description: Through the main protagonist Dave, we hear and see what it is like to be in love and have those feelings trapped inside. As we are let into Dave’s world, we see him and a group of friends as they leave school and embark on their journey home. The film flicks between two worlds of fantasy and real-life as the journey progresses. As the narrative comes to an end, we watch the three friends depart and Dave is left alone. His love unknown, unsaid but only understood by the viewer.

results.title: Hunter Schafer went on live to expose Silq
results.brief_description: Trans actress and model Hunter Schafer went live on Instagram to expose Silq, a nightclub in Düsseldorf, for refusing her assistant entry because she is trans. Schafer connected with up to 30.1K of her followers in real time to call out the club as “not safe for transgender people”. @schaferfiles, a Twitter fan account for the actress, ensured that Schafer’s broadcast could be accessed beyond the live stream, screen recording and reposting the video to Twitter. The viral nature of Schafer’s video demonstrates the power of social media as a tool for activism.
results.title_for_label: Hunter Schafer went on live to expose Silq
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Trans actor and model Hunter Schafer went live on Instagram to expose Silq, a nightclub in Düsseldorf, for refusing her assistant entry because she is trans. Schafer connected with up to 30.1K of her followers in real time to call out the club as “not safe for transgender people”. @schaferfiles, a Twitter fan account for the actress, ensured that Schafer’s broadcast could be accessed beyond the live stream, screen recording and reposting the video to Twitter. The viral nature of Schafer’s video demonstrates the power of social media as a tool for activism.
description_for_label: Trans actor and model Hunter Schafer went live on Instagram to expose Düsseldorf nightclub Silq for refusing her assistant entry because she’s trans. Schafer connected with up to 30.1K of her followers in real time to call out the club. @schaferfiles, a Twitter fan account, ensured that Schafer’s broadcast could be accessed beyond the live stream, screen recording and reposting the video to Twitter. Schafer’s viral video demonstrates the power of social media as a tool for activism.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: 'Screen It' 2011 - Winners
results.brief_description:
‘Screen It’ was Australia’s national film, animation and game making competition for school-aged students, run by ACMI for 16 years to 2019.

Designed to encourage imagination and inventiveness in primary and secondary school students, ‘Screen It’ fostered a new generation of young media makers. In 2011 budding young film and game-makers took up the challenge of creating their own short film or game in response to the theme ‘Respect.’

Witness first-hand the amazing winning entries of the 2011 Screen It competition!
results.description:
‘Screen It’ was Australia’s national film, animation and game making competition for school-aged students, run by ACMI for 16 years to 2019.

Designed to encourage imagination and inventiveness in primary and secondary school students, ‘Screen It’ fostered a new generation of young media makers. In 2011 budding young film and game-makers took up the challenge of creating their own short film or game in response to the theme ‘Respect.’

Witness first-hand the amazing winning entries of the 2011 Screen It competition!

Witness first-hand the amazing winning entries of the 2011 Screen It competition!

group_works.title: Twin [game trailer]
group_works.creator_credit: Nicholas Lee and James Ruse Agricultural High

results.title: The World As We Know It
results.creator_credit: Sunbury Downs College and Shannon Castle
results.brief_description:
A figure, shown by stop-motion animation, much like a zombie, walks through a world in pain. The Earth and people on it are being treated unfairly. Only if the figure wakes up to the fact that we need to respect the world and its inhabitants will the world become a better place.
Under the category ‘Secondary Animation’, Sunbury Downs College’s Shannon Castle, Year 9, was the Screen It 2011 winner.

results.title: Twin [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Lee and James Ruse Agricultural High
results.brief_description:
‘Twin’ is a videogame that highlights the importance of self-respect. It is based upon the Hero’s search for those who took away his ‘colour’. As his colour has been taken away, he has been reduced to his black and white form; his own being is split into two. The Hero realises his colour was in fact not stolen and by being able to overcome the puzzles and challenges brought by each level, the Hero begins to respect himself and is ultimately able to retrieve his ‘colours.’

A 2D problem solving/puzzle showing respect starts with self. This trailer illustrates how the game is played.
Under the category ‘Secondary Games’, James Ruse Agricultural High School’s Nicholas Lee, Year 12, was the Screen It 2011 winner.
